floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood.  Llanymynech and Maesbrook levels have peaked. Predicted peaks:- Cae Howel 3.3m to 3.5m Saturday afternoon, 22/05. 
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 18:00 on 22/05/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Lower Swale remains in force due to high river levels in the mid and lower Swale catchment, as a result of yesterdayâ€™s rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Further showers are expected through the weekend which is expected to keep levels high. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday afternoon, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the Lower Dunsforth Access has been removed as levels on the River Ure are continuing to fall slowly. There may still be standing water on low-lying land near rivers. Further showers are expected through the weekend and we are continuing to monitor the situation.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Lower Ure has been removed as river levels have fallen below levels of concern. Further showers are possible through today and tomorrow.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are rising at the Farndon river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, we believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Please be aware that access to Townfield Lane could be cut off due to high river levels. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.  
This message will be updated tomorrow, Saturday 22nd May, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park
items.message: The flood warning for the River Ure at Roecliffe has been removed as river levels have fallen below levels of concern. Further showers are possible throughout today and tomorrow.

The flood alert for the upper river Wharfe has been removed as levels on the upper river Wharfe are continuing to fall slowly. There may still be standing water on low-lying land near rivers. Further showers are expected through the weekend and we are continuing to monitor the situation.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Brokenborough river gauge as a result of rainfall on Thursday and Friday.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible until Monday 24/05/2021.  We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Saturday will be mostly dry.  River levels are currently falling, but expected to rise again on Sunday evening as a result of further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated by 11:00 on Sunday, 23/05/2021, or as the situation changes.

This flood warning has been removed as river levels on the Upper Wharfe have fallen. There may still be standing water on low-lying land near rivers. Further showers are expected through the weekend and we are continuing to monitor the situation.
The flood alert for the Lower River Nidd catchment has been removed as river levels have fallen below levels of concern. Further showers are possible through today and tomorrow.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper Ouse remains in force due to rising river levels as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of low lying footpaths, roads and farmland is possible. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday afternoon, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Old Wye Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. Hay on Wye and Bredwardine have now peaked. Predicted peaks:- Belmont 4.3m to 4.5m Saturday morning 22/05, Old Wye Bridge 3.9m to 4.1m Saturday morning on 22/05, Mordiford 3.8m to 4.0m Saturday morning, Ross on Wye 3.1m to 3.6m Saturday evening on 22/05.  
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 18:00 on 22/05/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn  bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 5.3m to 5.5m Saturday afternoon, 22/05
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 18:00 on 22/05/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.      
We continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Bollin catchment, including Knutsford, Wilmslow, Macclesfield and Bollington

floodArea.county: Cheshire East, Manchester, Stockport, Trafford, Warrington

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Bollington Mill river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland is possible this evening. We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the Rivers Bollin, Dean and Pedley, Birkin and Mobberley Brooks and their tributaries. We expect river levels to rise at Prestbury. 
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary.  
Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow 22/05/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. Predicted Peaks:- Ross on Wye 3.1m to 3.6m on Saturday evening, 22/05.
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 18:00 on 22/05/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Cheswick Green river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 22/05/21.  Flooding is expected to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 23/05/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent catchment remains in force. River levels have risen as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday 22nd May. The area most at risk is low lying land around Low Marishes. Further showers are expected over the next few days which is expected to keep levels high. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday afternoon, 22/05/2021 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: The flood warning for riverside properties in York remains in force as levels are rising following recent rainfall. Consequently flooding of properties, gardens, roads and paths is possible today, Saturday 22nd May. The River Ouse in York is forecast to peak at roughly 3.2m today, 22/05/2021. Further showers are possible throughout today and tomorrow. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and visit the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast and current river levels. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message on Saturday afternoon, or as the situation changes.

The flood warning for the River Ouse at Naburn Lock remains in force due to rising river levels following recent rainfall. The level of the River Ouse in York is currently 3.1m, and is expected to continue to rise steadily throughout this morning, Saturday 22nd May, reaching approximately 3.2m. The area most at risk is around Naburn Lock. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday afternoon, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of recent persistent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday 22/05/21. Flooding is expected to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to rise until later this morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 23/05/21, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the River Seven catchment has now been issued. River levels have risen overnight as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Saturday 22/05/2021.  Areas most at risk are low lying land around the River Rye and its tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck and Spittle Beck. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Saturday afternoon, 22/05/2021 or as the situation changes.
